{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox holiday | holiday_name = Cyber Monday | type = commercial | longtype = | image = | caption = Shoppers on Cyber Monday | duration = 1 day | frequency = annual | observedby = [[New Zealand]], [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Italy]], [[Iceland]], [[Brazil]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Romania]], [[South Africa]], [[South Korea]], [[Portugal]], [[Uganda]], [[Germany]], [[UAE]], [[Egypt]], [[Netherlands]], [[Finland]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Peru]], [[Japan]], [[Argentina]], [[Israel]], and [[Ireland]] | date = after [[Thanksgiving (United States)|U.S. Thanksgiving]] | celebrations = [[Shopping]] / [[Consumerism]] | relatedto = [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]], [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]], [[Small Business Saturday]], and [[Giving Tuesday]] }} '''Cyber Monday''' is a marketing term for the Monday after the [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] holiday in the [[United States]]. It was created by retailers to encourage people to [[online shopping|shop online]]. The term was coined by [[Ellen Davis (businesswoman)|Ellen Davis]] and Scott Silverman, and made its debut on November 28, 2005 in a [[Shop.org]] press release entitled "'Cyber Monday' Quickly Becoming One of the Biggest Online Shopping Days of the Year".{{cite news |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cyber-monday-quickly-becoming-one-of-the-biggest-online-shopping-days-of-the-year-55695037.html |title='Cyber Monday' Quickly Becoming One of the Biggest Online Shopping Days of the Year | work= Shop.org}} It is on the Monday after Thanksgiving, and most of the time falls in November, but if Thanksgiving is on November 27 or 28, it will fall in December. The date range is November 26 to December 2, and is always four days after the holiday. According to the Shop.org/[[Bizrate]] Research 2005 eHoliday Mood Study, "77 percent of online retailers said that their sales increased substantially on the Monday after Thanksgiving, a trend that is driving serious online discounts and promotions on Cyber Monday this year (2005)". In 2017, Cyber Monday online sales grew to a record $6.59 billion, compared with $2.98 billion in 2015, and $2.65 billion in 2014. However, the average order value was $128, down slightly from 2014's $160.{{cite web|url=http://www.fundivo.com/stats/cyber-monday-statistics/|title=Cyber Monday Statistics and Trends|publisher=}} Cyber Monday has become the online equivalent to [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] and offers a way for smaller retail websites to compete with larger chains.{{cite news|last=Swider|first=Matt|title=Cyber Monday 2017|url=http://www.techradar.com/news/cyber-monday-2017-the-best-deals|work=TechRadar|accessdate=November 23, 2017|language=en|deadurl=no}} Since its inception, it has become an international marketing term used by online retailers across the world. ==Origin of term== The term "Cyber Monday" was coined by [[Ellen Davis (businesswoman)|Ellen Davis]],{{cite news|last1=Tschorn|first1=Adam|title=Cyber Monday? Not so much|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/nov/18/image/ig-online18|accessdate=May 20, 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 18, 2007}}{{cite news|last1=Sutter|first1=John D.|title=Why 'Cyber Monday' is mostly myth|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/TECH/web/11/29/cyber.monday.hoax/|accessdate=May 20, 2015|date=November 29, 2010|work=[[CNN]]}} and was first used within the [[Electronic commerce|ecommerce]] community during the 2005 holiday season. According to Scott Silverman, the head of Shop.org, the term was coined based on 2004 research showing "one of the biggest online shopping days of the year" was the Monday after Thanksgiving (12th-biggest day historically).{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} Retailers also noted the biggest period was December 5 through 15 of the previous year. In late November 2005, ''The New York Times'' reported: "The name Cyber Monday grew out of the observation that millions of otherwise productive working Americans, fresh off a Thanksgiving weekend of window shopping, were returning to high-speed Internet connections at work Monday and buying what they liked."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/30/technology/30iht-cyber.html?scp=12&sq=cyber%20Thursday&st=cse |title=Online sales take off on 'Cyber Monday' |date=November 11, 2005 |work=The New York Times |author= Michael Barbaro}} At the time, a lot of people had slow Internet at home.{{cite news|url=http://www.greensboro.com/business/local_business/cyber-monday-overtakes-black-friday-as-top-shopping-day/article_8a47c851-53c8-5a68-879e-313b3d7b22d6.html|title=Cyber Monday overtakes Black Friday as top shopping day|last=Barron|first=Richard M.|work=[[News and Record]]|date=November 23, 2017|accessdate=November 24, 2017}} ==United States== ===Online spending=== In 2006, comScore reported that online spending on Cyber Monday jumped 25% to $608 million,{{cite news |url=http://www.comscore.com/Press_Events/Press_Releases/2006/11/Cyber_Monday_E-Commerce_Beats_Forecast | date = November 2006 | title=Cyber Monday E-Commerce Spending Beats Forecast; Climbs 25 Percent Versus Last Year to $608 Million |work= comScore}} 21% to $733 million in 2007,{{cite news | date = December 2007 | url = http://www.comscore.com/Press_Events/Press_Releases/2007/12/Cyber_Monday_Holiday_E-Commerce |title=Cyber Monday Spending Propels Holiday E-Commerce to Strong Week of More than $4 Billion in Sales | work = comScore}} and 15% to $846 million in 2008.{{cite news | url = http://www.comscore.com/Press_Events/Press_Releases/2008/12/Cyber_Monday_Sales_Reach_846_Million | title = E-Commerce Spending Jumps 15 Percent on Cyber Monday to $846 Million, the Second Heaviest Online Spending Day on Record | date = December 2008 |work=comScore}} In 2009, comScore reported that online spending increased 5 percent on Cyber Monday to $887 million and that more than half of dollars spent online at US Web sites originated from work computers (52.7 percent), representing a gain of 2.3 percentage points from last year.{{cite news | url = http://www.comscore.com/Press_Events/Press_Releases/2009/12/Cyber_Monday_Online_Sales_Up_5_Percent_vs._Year_Ago_to_887_Million_to_Match_Heaviest_Online_Spending_Day_in_History | title = Cyber Monday Online Sales Up 5 Percent vs. Year Ago to $887 Million to Match Heaviest Online Spending Day in History | date = December 2009 | work = comScore}} Buying from home comprised the majority of the remaining share (41.6 percent) while buying from international locations accounted for 5.8 percent. According to comScore chairman Gian Fulgoni, "comScore data have shown that Cyber Monday online sales have always been driven by considerable buying activity from work locations. That pattern hasn't changed. After returning from the long Thanksgiving weekend with a lot of holiday shopping still ahead of them, many consumers tend to continue their holiday shopping from work. Whether to take advantage of the extensive Cyber Monday deals offered by retailers or to buy gifts away from the prying eyes of family members, this day has become an annual ritual for America's online holiday shoppers." In 2010, comScore reported the first-ever $1 billion online shopping day ($1028M), an increase of 16 percent over 2009.{{cite news | url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/sns-ap-us-holiday-shopping,0,5612342.story| title= Cyber Monday biggest spending day online ever, firm says sales top $1 billion|last=Anderson|first=Mae|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=December 1, 2010|accessdate=December 2, 2010}} In 2011, comScore reported that Cyber Week saw US consumers spend over $6 billion online from November 28 to December 2.{{cite news |title='Cyber Week' Results in Record Online Spending of $6 Billion |work=WBNG |date=December 6, 2011 |url=http://www.wbng.com/news/state/135055538.html/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212232748/http://www.wbng.com/news/state/135055538.html |archivedate=December 12, 2013 |df= }} In 2012, comScore reported that Cyber Monday saw a 17% increase in sales from 2011, totaling $1.465 billion.{{cite news | url = http://bestcyberweek.com/articles/prediction-results-2012 | title = Cyber Monday Prediction Results for 2012 | date = August 2013 | work = BestCyberWeek.com}} In 2013, Cyber Monday sales continued their growth and recorded their highest grossing day ever at $2.29 billion.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} In 2014, the average planned expenditure is $361 per person. 46 percent people expect to pay with credit cards and 43 percent expect to pay with debit cards.{{cite news | url= http://www.ibtimes.com/black-friday-2014-why-most-americans-wont-shop-black-friday-or-cyber-monday-1725906| title= Black Friday 2014: Why Most Americans Won’t Shop On Black Friday Or Cyber Monday|last= Menton |first=Jessica|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=November 19, 2014|accessdate=November 19, 2014}} Sales are up 8.1% as of 6 p.m. ET, according to IBM Digital Analytics. The average order is $131.66, flat with last year, though the number of transactions is up and people are buying more items on average per order.{{cite news|last1=De Dios|first1=Princess Eilaine|title=Cyber Monday sales trend higher|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/12/01/cyber-week-deals-begin/19733541/|accessdate=December 2, 2014}} In 2016, according to Adobe Digital Insights,{{cite web|url=http://www.cmo.com/adobe-digital-insights/articles/2016/11/8/2016-holiday-shopping-up-to-the-minute-data-from-adi.html|title=2016 Holiday Shopping: Up-To-The-Minute Data From ADI|publisher=}} Cyber Monday hit a new record with $3.45 billion, and which was the first time that online sales in one single day surpassed $3 billion in US history. The numbers went up 12.1% from the previous year.{{cite web|url=http://mothod.com/trends/online-sales-cyber-monday-hit-new-record/|title=Online sales on Cyber Monday hit a new record - MOTHOD|date=November 30, 2016|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: right" |+ Cyber Monday Online Sales
{{small|Source: comScore, Inc.}} |- !Day!!Year!!Sales
(millions
of USD)!!% Change |- | November 27||2006||$610||N/A |- | November 26||2007||$730||{{increase}} 20% |- | December 1||2008||$846||{{increase}} 16% |- | November 30||2009||$887||{{increase}} 4.7% |- | November 29||2010||$1,028||{{increase}} 16% |- | November 28||2011||$1,251||{{increase}} 22% |- | November 26||2012||$1,465||{{increase}} 17% |- | December 2||2013||$1,735||{{increase}} 18% |- | December 1||2014||$2,038{{cite web|url=https://www.comscore.com/Insights/Press-Releases/2014/12/Cyber-Monday-Exceeds-2-Billion-in-Desktop-Sales-for-First-Time-Ever-to-Rank-as-Heaviest-US-Online-Spending-Day-in-History|title=Cyber Monday Exceeds $2 Billion in Desktop Sales for First Time Ever to Rank as Heaviest U.S. Online Spending Day in History|publisher=}}||{{increase}} 17% |- | November 30||2015||$2,280||{{increase}} 12% |- | November 28||2016||$2,671||{{increase}} 17% |- | November 27||2017||$3,364||{{increase}} 26% |- |- | November 26||2018|| || |} ===Employers and online shopping=== U.S. employers have been cracking down on employees using company equipment and company time for non-work-related purposes, including Cyber Monday. As of November 2011, 22% of employers had fired an employee for using the Internet for non-work related activity; 7% of human resource managers surveyed had fired an employee for holiday shopping; and 54% of employers were blocking employees from accessing certain websites.{{cite news | url = http://jobs.aol.com/articles/2011/11/22/shopping-on-the-clock-cyber-monday-in-the-workplace-infographi/ | title = Shopping On The Clock: Cyber Monday In The Workplace |work= aol.com |accessdate=November 27, 2011}}{{cite news | url = http://www.cybermondaysniper.com/safety/ | title = Staying Safe Online On Cyber Monday | work = www.cybermondaysniper.com/ | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140913055413/http://www.cybermondaysniper.com/safety/ | archivedate = 2014-09-13 | df = }} According to CareerBuilder's annual Cyber Monday survey, more than half of workers (53%) say they spend at least some work time holiday shopping on the Internet, up 3% from 2015. Of this group, 43% spend an hour or more doing so, compared to 42% from 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.careerbuilder.com/share/aboutus/pressreleasesdetail.aspx?sd=11/22/2016&id=pr978&ed=12/31/2016|title=53% of Employees Are Using Time at Work to Shop Online, Increase From Last Year, Finds Annual CareerBuilder Survey - CareerBuilder|website=www.careerbuilder.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-13}} ==Other countries== ===Americas=== ====Argentina==== According to Argentine press, Cyber Monday was celebrated on November 11, 2014, and marked a tenfold growth in users taking advantage of online sales over the previous year.{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/sociedad/cyber_monday-descuentos_online-turismo-tecnologia-consumo_0_1246675383.html|title=Cyber Monday: creció 10 veces la cantidad de compradores |last1= |first1= |date=November 11, 2014 |website=Clarín.com |language=Spanish |accessdate=November 12, 2014}} ====Canada==== Cyber Monday came to Canada in 2008. The ''[[National Post]]'' featured an article, in the November 25, 2010, edition, stating that the parity of the [[Canadian dollar]] with the [[United States dollar|US dollar]] caused many Canadian retailers to have [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] and Cyber Monday sales of their own. According to the article, an estimated 80% of Canadians were expected to participate in Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales.{{Cite journal | publisher = National Post | title = Retail therapy: Canadians prep for black Friday, cyber Thursday | date = November 25, 2010 | url = http://arts.nationalpost.com/2010/11/25/retail-therapy-canadians-prep-for-black-friday-cyber-Thursday/ | series = Arts | postscript = {{inconsistent citations}}}}. Speculation has been made that with all major US television broadcasters—which are typically available to Canadians—emphasizing Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales for stores that are also doing business in Canada, Canadian retailers needed to mimic sales offerings in order to keep Canadian dollars from being spent in the US. By 2011, around 80% of online retailers in Canada were participating in Cyber Monday.[https://www.thestar.com/specialsections/blackfriday/article/1291394--canadian-retailers-fight-back-against-black-friday-deals Canadian retailers fight back against Black Friday deals], Toronto Start 2012 ====Chile==== Chile's first Cyber Monday took place on November 28, 2011. The companies participating in the event are participants in the Santiago Chamber of Commerce's Electronic Commerce Committee.{{Cite journal | url = http://www.lasegunda.com/Noticias/Economia/2011/11/699639/Chile-tendra-su-primer-Cyber-Monday-con-ineditas-ofertas-online | publisher = La segunda | date = November 2011 | language = Spanish| series = Noticias | title= Chile tendra su primer cyber Monday con ineditas ofertas en linea | postscript = {{inconsistent citations}}}} In 2015 the Chilean Cyber Monday had 85 stores participating, 390.000 transactions and US$83 million in sales. 36% of that was mobile.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cybermonday.cl/info.html|title=Cyberday 2016|website=Cyberday - Chile|language=es-cl|access-date=2016-11-04}} In 2016 Cyber Monday will be held on November 7. 140 companies are registered as official partners. ====Colombia==== The first Cyber Monday in Colombia took place on November 26, 2012. It was organized by the Colombian Chamber of Electronic Commerce and sponsored by the Ministry of IT and Telecommunications.{{Cite web | url = http://www.cyberlunes.com.co/noticia/celebre_el_primer_cyberlunes_oficial_en_colombia | date = November 25, 2012 | language = Spanish| work = Cyberlunes.com.co | title = Celebre el primer cyberlunes oficial en Colombia | postscript = {{inconsistent citations}}}} ===Asia=== ====India==== {{See also|E-commerce in India}} India got its own version of the Cyber Monday ([[Great Online Shopping Festival]]) on December 12, 2012 when [[Google]] India partnered with many e-commerce companies including [[Flipkart]], [[Snapdeal]], [[HomeShop18]], [[Indiatimes shopping]], and [[MakeMyTrip]]. Google said that this was the first time an industry-wide initiative of this scale was undertaken.{{cite news|title=Google partners e-commerce sites for 'Cyber Monday' on December 12|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-12-04/news/35594711_1_operations-rajan-anandan-google-india-md-online-travel-sites|accessdate=December 31, 2012|newspaper=The Economic Times|date=December 4, 2012}} In November 2015, Google announced that the event would not be repeated.{{cite news|title=Google logs out of its flagship Online Shopping Festival GOSF|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/internet/google-logs-out-of-its-flagship-online-shopping-festival-gosf/articleshow/49643856.cms|accessdate=November 29, 2016|newspaper=The Economic Times|date=November 4, 2015}} ====Japan==== Amazon.co.jp announced it registered as Cyber Monday with Japan Anniversary Association in 2012. Amazon.co.jp ran the Cyber Monday Seven Day Sale from Dec 10 through December 16, 2012.{{cite news | location = JP | url= https://www.amazon.co.jp/gp/press/pr/20121129/ |title=Amazon.co.jp registered Cyber Monday with Japan Anniversary Association | language = Japanese | accessdate =December 1, 2012}} ===Europe=== ====Belgium==== In Belgium, Cyber Monday has gained popularity since 2016. Due to efforts off several major online shops launching large Cyber Monday campaigns, the average revenue during Cyber Monday has increased with 50% compared to the 2015 edition.{{cite web| location = BE | language = Dutch| url = https://www.blackfridayexpert.be/wanneer-is-cyber-monday/ |title= Wanneer is Cyber Monday? |accessdate =October 22, 2017}} ====France==== Inspired by the U.S. phenomenon, the term Cyber Monday was first used in France in 2008.{{cite news |url= http://www.zdnet.fr/actualites/le-24-novembre-le-cyberThursday-debarque-en-france-39385034.htm | language = French | title=Le 24 novembre, le Cybermonday débarque en France |work=ZDNet | location = France |accessdate=August 24, 2010}} ====Germany==== Amazon.de announced that it brought Cyber Monday to Germany in 2010.{{cite news | location = DE | url= http://www.presseportal.de/pm/8337/1709547/amazon_de_gmbh |title=Amazon.de bringt Cyber Monday nach Deutschland | language = German | work = Presseportal | accessdate =November 3, 2011}} As of 2014, amazon.de continues to advertise Cyber Monday and has extended it to an 8-day period ("Cyber Monday week") beginning on the Monday before [[Thanksgiving]]. ====Netherlands==== In the Netherlands, the term Cyber Monday was first used in 2012. Since then, Dutch online retailers have taken advantage of Cyber Monday in promotional purposes, because it is perfectly timed before the celebration of [[Sinterklaas]] which is celebrated by buying gifts for each other in Netherlands.{{cite web| location = NL | language = Dutch| url = https://www.cybermondaynederland.nl/ |title=Cyber Monday, de online uitverkoop van Nederland! |accessdate =October 17, 2016}} Since 2012, the popularity of Cyber Monday has grown strongly every year in the Netherlands. In total there were 105 participating online stores during the Cyber Monday period of 2017.{{cite news |url= https://www.blackfridaynederland.nl/cyber-monday-2018/ |title= Cyber Monday 2018 | date= July 26, 2018 |language= nl}} ====Portugal==== In Portugal, the term Cyber Monday was first used in 2009.{{cite news | location = PT | language = Portuguese | url = http://www.ionline.pt/conteudo/34416-lojas-online-fazem-uma-semana-descontos-loucos |title=Lojas online fazem uma semana de descontos loucos |work=Jornal i | accessdate =November 18, 2010}} ====Romania==== In Romania, Cyber Monday is the first Monday after Black Friday, which is held by the biggest retailers one week before the US Black Friday. ====Sweden==== In Sweden Cyber Monday is growing rapidly and several of the largest online retailers regularly launch Cyber Monday campaigns.{{Cite web|url = http://www.ehandel.se/Naethandlarnas-Cyber-Monday-slog-nya-rekord,3364.html|title = Näthandlarnas Cyber Monday slog nya rekord|date = 2013-12-04|accessdate = 2014-11-25|website = Ehandel.se|publisher = Ehandel.se|last = |first = }} Cyber Monday was first established on larger online retailers in Sweden 2010.{{Cite web|url = http://www.ehandel.se/Cyber-Monday-aer-redan-haer,993.html|title = Cyber Monday är redan här|date = 2011-11-29|accessdate = 2014-11-25|website = Ehandel.se|publisher = Ehandel.se|last = |first = }} ====United Kingdom==== According to a 2009 ''The Guardian'' article, UK online retailers are now referring to "Cyber Monday" as the busiest internet shopping day of the year that commonly falls on the same day as the US Cyber Monday.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/nov/23/amazon-christmas-online-shopping-cyber-Thursday | title =Amazon gets set for cyber Monday as Christmas shopping online clicks — Internet retailers are preparing for a deluge of online orders on their busiest day of the year in the lead-up to Christmas | accessdate = November 23, 2009 | publisher = The Guardian | last = Teather | first = David | location = London | date = November 23, 2009}} ===Oceania=== ====Australia==== Beginning at 7 pm [[AEDT]] on November 20 in 2012, Australian online retailers decided to hold a similar event for the first time, dubbed "Click Frenzy". Many websites immediately crashed, went offline, or had major server issues, including the Click Frenzy promotion website. David Jones, a major retailer, ran a competing sale dubbed 'Christmas Frenzy' on the same date. ====New Zealand==== Online retailer Belly Beyond held the first Cyber Monday Sale in New Zealand on November 29, 2010.{{cite news | url = http://www.esquire.com/the-side/feature/cyber-Thursday-online-shopping-4021548 | title = The Accidentally-on-Purpose History of Cyber Monday |work= Esquire |accessdate=November 29, 2010}} The sale lasted for five days, from Monday to Friday. ==See also== *[[Green Monday]] *[[Black Friday (shopping)]] *[[Buy Nothing Day]] *[[Small Business Saturday]] *[[Super Saturday|Super Saturday (Panic Saturday)]] *[[Giving Tuesday]] *[[Singles' Day]] ==References== {{reflist|35em}} {{Thanksgiving}} {{Christmas}} [[Category:E-commerce]] [[Category:Unofficial observances]] [[Category:Words coined in the 2000s]] [[Category:Buzzword]] [[Category:Christmas economics]] [[Category:Monday observances]] [[Category:Observances based on the date of Thanksgiving (United States)]]

{{Infobox venue | name = | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = File:Dancehouse (Melbourne) entrance.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = 150 Princes Street | location = Carlton North, Victoria | coordinates = {{Coord|-37.792169|144.9704912|type:landmark}} | type = | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | publictransit = }} '''Dancehouse''' is a centre for independent [[contemporary dance]] in the [[Carlton North, Victoria|Carlton North]] area of Melbourne, Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dancemagazine.com.au/2012/03/what-is-dancehouse/|title=What is Dancehouse? - Dance Informa Magazine|last=Edwards|first=Grace|date=March 2012|website=dancemagazine.com.au|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=24 September 2017}}</ref>
It was established in 1992 by a group of independent dance practitioners at the Carlton Hall in Princes Street, formerly occupied by the Carlton Community Centre. Carlton Hall, built in 1887, has a long association with dance as a venue for social dances, dance classes and dance performance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cchg.asn.au/news2.html|title=Fancy Footwork at Carlton Hall|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cchg.asn.au|publisher=Carlton Community History Group Inc|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=24 September 2017}}</ref>
Dancehouse contains three spaces – the 104-seat Sylvia Staehli Theatre, an Upstairs Studio and a gallery – used for performances and workshops. It holds curated performance seasons and residencies for dance artists, as well as masterclasses and other events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeout.com/melbourne/theatre/dancehouse|title=Dancehouse|work=Time Out Melbourne|access-date=24 September 2017|language=en-AU}}</ref>
It presents Melbourne's biennial Dance Massive festival with [[Arts House]] and [[Malthouse Theatre, Melbourne|Malthouse Theatre]], and is also involved with the Keir Choreographic Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.realtimearts.net/article/90/9397|title=RealTime Arts - Magazine - issue 90 - dance massive: intro|website=www.realtimearts.net|language=en-AU|author=Keith Gallasch|access-date=24 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeout.com/melbourne/theatre/dance-massive|title=Dance Massive|work=Time Out Melbourne|access-date=24 September 2017|language=en-AU|author=Dee Jefferson|date=5 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/dance/keir-choreographic-award-leaps-into-discussion-about-the-future-of-dance-20160418-go8qnb.html|title=Keir Choreographic Award leaps into discussion about the future of dance|last=Hawker|first=Philippa|date=18 April 2016|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|access-date=24 September 2017|language=en-AU}}</ref>
