revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{lead too short|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox video game | title = The Bureau: XCOM Declassified | image = File:Bureau XCOM Declassified cover.png | developer = [[2K Marin]]
[[2K Australia]]
[[2K China]] | publisher = [[2K Games]] | director = Morgan Gray | designer = Zak McClendon | producer = John Chowanec
Alyssa Finley | artist = Jeff Weir | writer = Erik Caponi | series = ''[[X-COM]]'' | engine = [[Unreal Engine 3]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[OS X]] | released = {{vgrelease|NA|August 20, 2013{{cite web|last=Parfitt |first=Ben |url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/xcom-gets-2012-release |title=XCOM gets 2012 release | Games industry news | MCV |publisher=Mcvuk.com |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}|PAL|August 23, 2013}}'''OS X'''{{vgrelease|WW|November 27, 2013}} | genre = [[Tactical shooter]], [[third-person shooter]] | modes = [[Single-player]] }} '''''The Bureau: XCOM Declassified''''' is a science fiction video game in the ''[[X-COM]]'' series, developed by [[2K Marin]] and was released by [[2K Games]] for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] on August 20, 2013 in North America. It was released for [[Mac OS|Mac]] on November 27, 2013 by Transgaming. The game had been in development under different titles by three different studios since 2006. It was unveiled as a [[first-person shooter]] titled ''XCOM'' in June 2010 and was repeatedly delayed until its release. In April 2013, the game was rebranded as ''The Bureau: XCOM Declassified''. In its final version, it became a third-person [[tactical shooter]] with [[strategy video game]] elements. ==Gameplay== [[File:Bureau XCOM Declassified screenshot.jpg|left|thumb|The game's Battle Focus Mode]] ''The Bureau'' is a [[third-person shooter]] with an emphasis on squad-based tactics. The player controls the agent William Carter and commands two additional agents in each mission. Carter has several unique abilities, such as healing his entire squad, lifting enemies out of cover, and summoning [[Unmanned combat aerial vehicle|combat drones]]. The other agents are divided into four classes: Commando, Engineer, Support, and Recon. Each class is proficient in a different set of powers and weapon types. For example, the Commando class is specialized in offensive abilities and [[rifle]]s, while the Engineer class relies on [[land mine]]s, [[Sentry gun|automatic turrets]], and the use of [[shotgun]]s. As Carter and his squad gain more experience points during missions, more abilities become available. By entering "Battle Focus Mode", which slows time significantly, the player can order their agents to move to tactical positions and activate class-specific abilities. Agents have customizable outfits, weapons, equipment, and abilities. As in ''[[XCOM: Enemy Unknown]]'', if Carter is unable to revive agents who have taken too much damage, they will die (variable difficulty levels also determine whether or not it is possible for downed agents to become battle-ready when revived, or if replacement agents will appear during a mission). The agents who die will be dead for the rest of the game. Throughout the course of the game, the player can collect backpack schematics and alien weapons, which then become available for the entire squad. Each backpack provides a unique bonus to the agent wearing it. For example, the Sharpshooter Pack provides bonus head-shot damage, and the Guardian Pack reduces damage taken from attacks. These equipments can be altered before a mission, or at Resupply Stations located in each mission. {{clear left}} ==Synopsis== ===Setting=== The game is set in late 1962, at the height of the [[Cold War]] between the [[United States]] and [[Soviet Union]]. Prior to the events of the game, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[John F. Kennedy]] authorized the creation of the Bureau of Strategic Emergency Command, which was intended to coordinate [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. military forces]] in the event of a Soviet invasion of the USA. A top-secret underground command bunker was constructed to house the Bureau, and specific military and civilian personnel were secretly contacted and told to report there in the event of an invasion. The Bureau's director, Myron Faulke, had another vision for his organization: a bulwark against attacks from "Outsiders", hostile [[extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrial forces]] whom he believed had been operating on Earth for the past six months and had some connection to the recently discovered "super-element" Elerium. As the game begins, [[CIA]] [[special agent]] William Carter is tasked with delivering an important package to Faulke at the Bureau's research labs at [[Groom Range]]. ===Plot=== Waiting in a room at the Groom Range facility for Director Faulke's summons, William Carter meets a military officer who informs him that she is to escort him to Faulke to deliver a briefcase. When a wary Carter refuses, a black fluid discharges from the officer's eyes, revealing her to be "infected"; she then shoots Carter and opens the case. It emits a blinding light which incinerates the officer and stuns Carter. Moments later, Carter awakens to find his gunshot wound inexplicably healed and the case destroyed as the base comes under attack. Carter attempts to rescue Faulke as the attackers, identified as "Outsiders" by Bureau agents whom Carter encounters, easily slaughter the base's garrison. He eventually finds Faulke, but is too late to save the VIP officials [[J. Edgar Hoover]], CIA Director Frost, and General Deems, the latter of whom had become infected (in the same manner as the female officer) and killed the other officials. Carter escapes the Groom Range facility by tram just as Outsider devices cause the mountain to implode, and stalls the Outsider pursuit by detonating a powerful Elerium bomb while he and Faulke flee via Skyranger helicopter. At the Bureau's command bunker, Faulke announces that communications worldwide have been jammed and other U.S. military bases have been destroyed in similar attacks. With no way to contact the [[White House]] and other American military leaders, Faulke formally activates the Bureau (now renamed XCOM) and assumes control of the country's remaining military forces to counter the Outsider threat, while Bureau operatives planted in major cities downplay the attacks as safety drills to keep the civilian populace from panicking. Over the following weeks, Carter leads teams of agents across the country to retrieve important personnel, defend strategic sites, and recover what alien technology they can for research. Gradually, the Bureau pieces together the Outsiders' motive: to conquer the Earth and terraform it into a new homeworld, simultaneously enslaving humanity. The interrogation of an Outsider Infiltrator reveals that their species is commanded by an entity known as Origin through a psionic network called Mosaic. Carter's team travels through a "Venn Portal" to their homeworld using the Avenger, a [[flying saucer]] XCOM has developed. There, Carter discovers that Mosaic is powered by an enslaved Ethereal, a being of pure energy with immense psionic power. The Outsiders have been searching for a dormant Ethereal on Earth, which is revealed to have been inside of Carter's briefcase from the game's opening and now inhabits his body. He manages to capture Origin's Ethereal, detonates a bomb at Mosaic's entry point and returns to Earth. At XCOM's base, the captured Ethereal, Shamash, psionically contacts the Ethereal inside of Carter, Asaru. It becomes apparent that the player has actually been playing as Asaru, who has in turn been psionically controlling William Carter, though its recently awakened state caused it to believe it truly was human. Shamash claims that because both the Outsiders and humans have learned how to capture Ethereal, they must be destroyed so that a force like Mosaic will never be rebuilt. Upon hearing this, Carter manages to temporarily break free of Asaru and kills Shamash. XCOM's base is discovered by the Outsiders, and Carter attempts to defend it, while actively attempting to break free from Asaru's control. Carter manages to plant an explosive device with a thirty-second timer, believing that the Ethereal will never truly allow him to be free. There are four endings depending on choices made at this point. If Asaru refuses to relinquish control of Carter, the bomb will go off, killing both of them. Alternatively, Asaru can release Carter, but only to willingly merge with either Dr. Weir, Agent Weaver, or Director Faulke. The new host will knock Carter unconscious and the remaining agents will abandon the base. They discover that Origin still exists within what remains of the Mosaic network, and has transported itself to Earth's orbit in order to command the Outsiders stranded on the planet. The crew of the Avenger mounts their final attack against Origin's ship, with Asaru providing the new host with the powers it had given Carter. During the mission, one of the other two host options must be sacrificed while the other is rescued, and Carter, who believes that Asaru is no different from the Outsiders, must be either executed or incarcerated. Eventually, Asaru's host discovers a secondary entry point for Mosaic and psionically integrates with the network, destroying Origin and its influence over the Outsiders. The aftermath of the Outsider invasion is revealed in the form of a debriefing of Asaru's host: *If Weir merges with Asaru, he persuades the Outsiders to cease attacking and help rebuild before departing amiably to continue their search for a homeworld; Outsider technology is carefully disassembled and stored away, sites of Outsider attacks are quietly erased from the National Register or explained away as natural disasters, and surviving Sleepwalkers are cured. *If Weaver merges, she forces the Outsiders to kill each other; all Outsider technology and evidence of their attacks is destroyed, in some cases with nuclear weapons, and the Sleepwalkers are euthanized. *If Faulke merges, he commands the Outsiders to stand down and rebuild before being exterminated; some Outsider technology is preserved and provides considerable scientific and military advances, sites of Outsider attacks are erased, and the Sleepwalkers are treated, but unable to be cured. In any case, the Outsider invasion is successfully covered up, with only the members of XCOM and a handful of top U.S. and other world leaders aware of how close the human race came to extinction. The debriefing concludes with a description of how Asaru eventually severs contact with its host and departs after the Outsiders are dealt with, and its intentions remain unknown. At this point, the musical score segues into a theme from ''XCOM: Enemy Unknown''. ==Development== In early 2006, [[Irrational Games]] was purchased by publisher [[Take-Two Interactive]], who had also acquired the ''[[X-COM]]'' [[Intellectual property|IP]] from [[Atari]] the year before. Shortly after, two Irrational studios in [[Boston]] (later renamed [[2K Boston]]) and [[Canberra]] (later renamed [[2K Australia]]) began conceptualization of a new game in the series.{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/features/2013/8/19/4614410/xcom-the-bureau-development-2006-2013 |title=The many faces of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified: from 2006 to 2013 |author=Chris Plante |publisher=Polygon |date=August 19, 2013 |accessdate=August 22, 2013}} The video gaming press picked up multiple hints on the development throughout the period leading up to the official reveal in 2010. In May 2006, Irrational Games announced they were hiring for a work "On the sequel to one of the best loved PC franchises of all time."{{cite web|author=Florian Eckhardt |url=http://kotaku.com/176971/irrational-hiring-for-pretty-please-system-shock-3 |title=Irrational Hiring For (Pretty Please) System Shock 3? |publisher=Kotaku |date=May 30, 2006 |accessdate=November 27, 2012}} By February 2007, there were unconfirmed rumors about a new ''X-COM'' game being developed by Irrational Games.{{cite web|last=Yurik |first=Poor |url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/45797/irrational-games-developing-x-com |title="Irrational Games Developing X-COM Title?" article |publisher=Shacknews |date= |accessdate=November 27, 2012}} Several concept pitches were created early on in the development. One was of a tactical strategy sequel to the original series that would be built on an upgraded ''[[Freedom Force (2002 video game)|Freedom Force]]'' engine. Another cast the player in the role of a human resistance leader in a post-invasion scenario, featuring highly stylized, cartoonish character models.{{cite web|url=http://www.benshore.com/Image_XComRebelGirl.htm |title=XCOM Rebel Girl – Ben Shore's Portfolio |publisher=Benshore.com |date= |accessdate=November 27, 2012}} One pitch, in which the player would be based on a hijacked alien craft, was even made into a full demo that was supposed to be shown at [[Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3]], but never was. However, much of the studios' resources were focused on the development of ''[[BioShock]]'' and on supporting [[BioShock 2|the sequel's]] development, which was handled by an ex-Irrational studio [[2K Marin]] in [[California]], so the pre-production progressed very slowly. The aforementioned concepts involving a post-invasion scenario and hijacked alien craft would eventually see implementation into ''[[XCOM 2]]'', developed by Firaxis Games as a sequel to ''XCOM: Enemy Unknown''. Upon the completion of ''[[BioShock 2]]'' in early 2010, the Canberra studio pitched a concept of the ''X-COM'' game as "the [[UFO: Enemy Unknown|original ''X-COM'']] meets ''[[The X-Files]]'', set in the 1950s to 1960s." The game was decided to be to a [[first-person shooter]] set in the 1950s and combining missions on the field with base management; an important part of the game would be taking photographs on the field for research. This green-lighted pitch was originally titled ''X-COM: Enemy Unknown'' (not to be confused with [[UFO: Enemy Unknown|the original ''X-COM'' game]] as well as [[XCOM: Enemy Unknown|the later game of the same name]]) and featured mysterious aliens taking abstract forms such as globs of black goo and levitating geometrical shapes, in addition to masquerading as humans in a manner reminiscent of the 1956 film ''[[Invasion of the Body Snatchers]]''. A [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] mode was also in development, described as similar in concept to the ''[[Aliens versus Predator (video game)|Aliens vs. Predator]]'' game series, but it was later scrapped altogether. The game was officially announced on April 14, 2010, titled simply ''XCOM''. In development for the Xbox 360 and PC, it was described as a "re-imagining of one of gaming's most storied and beloved franchises."{{cite web |url=http://ir.take2games.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=86428&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1412708&highlight= |title=2K Games Announces XCOM(R) - Suspense and Mystery-Filled First-Person Shooter from Creators of BioShock(R) 2 |author= |publisher=2K Games |date=April 14, 2010 |accessdate=August 22, 2013}} In-game footage was first shown at [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2010|E3 2010]] in June 2010.{{cite web|url=http://uk.pc.ign.com/articles/109/1096051p1.html |title=E3 2010: XCOM Preview – PC Preview at IGN |publisher=Uk.pc.ign.com |date=June 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} It was later retrospectively described as a [[survival horror]] title, "like a ''[[Silent Hill]]'' sort of game, where it's sort of the cerebral horror versus the run and gun horror game."{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/videos/2013/05/10/the-evolution-of-the-bureau-xcom-declassified |title=The Evolution of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified – Road to E3 Inside Look – IGN Video |publisher=Uk.ign.com |date=May 10, 2013 |accessdate=August 3, 2013}} Regarding a move away from the strategy genre, 2K Games president Christoph Hartmann said at the time "[[strategy game]]s are just not contemporary,"{{cite web|last=Dring |first=Christopher |url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/interview-christophhartmann-2kgames/082216 |title=INTERVIEW: Christoph Hartmann, 2K Games | Games industry news | MCV |publisher=Mcvuk.com |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} but the developers later assured they would keep elements from the original game, such as squad and base management, free-form non-linear mission progression, and squad-based tactical combat.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/5987/putting_the_xcom_in_xcom.php |title=Features – Putting the XCOM in XCOM |publisher=Gamasutra |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} ''XCOM'' was originally announced to arrive in 2011,{{cite web|last=Ramirez |first=Noe |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2012/01/09/first-screens-and-details-of-xcom-enemy-unknown.aspx |title=First Screens And Details Of XCOM: Enemy Unknown – Features |publisher=GameInformer.com |date=January 9, 2012 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} but then got repeatedly delayed. It was first officially rescheduled to launch on March 6, 2012, before being delayed again,{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2011/11/08/xcom-delayed-to-at-least-april/ |title=XCOM delayed between one and 12 months |publisher=PC Gamer |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} supposed to come out before March 31, 2013.{{cite web|last=Ivan |first=Tom |url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/332313/xcom-shooter-delayed-to-2013/ |title=News: XCOM shooter delayed to 2013 |publisher=ComputerAndVideoGames.com |date=January 16, 2012 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} By April 2012, it was estimated to be released between April 2013 and March 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/05/22/xcom-delayed-to-fiscal-2014 |title=XCOM Delayed Again |publisher=IGN |date=May 22, 2012 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} Already prior to the game's E3 2010 debut, the developers began experiencing various difficulties both creatively and technically. Earlier in the year, 2K publishing had assigned a large portion of 2K Marin to assist 2K Australia in developing the game, and soon the two studios were merged under the name "2K Marin". The Australian branch worked on the single-player component while the California branch was assigned the multiplayer mode (described as resembling ''[[Left 4 Dead]]'' and ultimately scrapped). However, the two "2K Marin" studios in California and Australia were slowed down by communication issues, and they found it difficult to implement the [[stealth game]]play and the themes of mystery and field research. The Australian studio also lost several key members, with the game's original lead designer Ed Orman and art director Andrew James leaving 2K Marin to form Uppercut Games in 2011.{{cite web|author=July 11, 11 |url=http://www.neoseeker.com/news/16852-xcom-lead-designer-art-director-leave-2k-marin/ |title=XCOM lead designer & art director leave 2K Marin |publisher=Neoseeker |date=July 11, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}{{cite web|last=McElroy |first=Justin |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/07/11/former-xcom-leads-form-uppercut-games-unveil-epoch/ |title=Former XCOM leads form Uppercut Games, unveil Epoch |publisher=Joystiq |date=July 11, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} The American branch gradually took upon a leading role, having been forced to abandon development of their own new IP and to finish up what was supposed to be a quick release of ''X-COM''. {{quote box|quote=Candidly, it just wasn't ''[[X-COM]]'' enough for the hardcore fans of the original games at [[2K Marin]], who serve as our creative conscience. So over the past year, we’ve made some pretty aggressive design changes, in pursuit of the feelings that we experienced when we played the original games.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2011/08/26/xcom-video-walkthrough-brings-22-minutes-of-joyheresy/ |title=XCOM video walkthrough brings 22 minutes of joy/heresy |publisher=PC Gamer |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}|source=Jordan Thomas, ''XCOM'' narrative director 2011-2012|width=30%|}} Following widespread criticism of the original project from ''X-COM'' fan community and parts of the media, as well as the problems with developing the game, ''XCOM'' got thoroughly revamped by 2011, evolving into a linear [[tactical shooter]] (with no randomized missions and no stealth and detective gameplay elements, but with more control over other agents) seen from a third-person view (the [[E3 2011]] demo version showed a first-person shooter gameplay nevertheless). The setting was also changed, including an introduction of humanoid enemies and the timeline being pushed forward from the 1950s to 1962 in order to explore cultural tensions of the 1960s.{{cite web |url=http://gaygamer.net/2011/06/e3_11_interview_jordan_thomas.html |title=E3 '11: Interview: Jordan Thomas On XCOM And Homosexuality |publisher=GayGamer.net |date= |accessdate=November 27, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028095115/http://gaygamer.net/2011/06/e3_11_interview_jordan_thomas.html |archivedate=October 28, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5812460/the-struggles-of-a-gay-xcom-scientist |title=The Struggles of a Gay XCOM Scientist |publisher=Kotaku.com |date=June 16, 2011 |accessdate=November 27, 2012}} The player could now enter a tactical-view mode, during which the game paused for a while, to "use [[time units]] to order the two agents traveling with him on the field."{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2011/06/24/why-did-2k-games-turn-xcom-into-a-fps-tactical-game-hybrid/ |title=Why Did 2K Games Turn XCOM Into A FPS-Tactical Game Hybrid? |publisher=Siliconera |date=June 24, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} According to [[GameSpy]], "the core aspects of the game are about working with a team of agents who have a variety of classes that you can customize, to have certain abilities that assist you on missions (think [[Party (role playing games)|RPG party]] building)," using "[[experience point]]s where you can level them up or upgrade them along different paths." The player was also offered to choose the missions from a variety of choices, "each offering different strategic options."{{cite web |last=Nelson |first=Mike |url=http://www.1up.com/previews/e3-xcom-preview |title=XCOM Preview for PC, 360 from |publisher=1UP.com |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711084048/http://www.1up.com/previews/e3-xcom-preview |archivedate=July 11, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} {{quote box|quote=I think – from a development perspective – we've been focused less on how to make it less like ''[[BioShock (series)|BioShock]]'' and I would counter and say we're trying to make it more like ''X-COM''. It's been like going to ''X-COM'' boot camp for the team, creatively – really understanding the core of the franchise.{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2011/06/21/aliens-ate-my-neighbors-2k-marins-gray-on-xcom/ |title=Aliens Ate My Neighbors: 2K Marin’s Gray on XCOM |publisher=VG247 |date=June 21, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}|source=Morgan Gray, ''XCOM'' creative director 2011-2013|width=30%|align=left}} In 2012, the game's narrative Jordan Thomas left the ''XCOM'' team, asked by [[Ken Levine (game developer)|Ken Levine]] to help 2K Boston finish ''[[BioShock Infinite]]'', while 2K Australia has regained its name and was also reassigned to a support work on ''Infinite''. Zak McClendon, the lead designer of ''BioShock 2'', became the lead designer for the struggling ''XCOM'' project. Following the success of ''XCOM: Enemy Unknown'', developed by [[Firaxis Games]] and released by 2K Games in October 2012, 2K Games decided to have both of the ''XCOM'' games related more closely to each other, including sharing some of the alien species such as the series' iconic Sectoids. Meanwhile, no new materials related to the game were officially released since the showing at E3 2011. In late 2012, the game was rumored by [[Kotaku]] to be "coming back as a [[third-person shooter]]. While the 1960s setting and general ''XCOM'' prequel vibe remains, it's now apparently being pitched as a squad-based game similar to ''[[SOCOM (series)|SOCOM]]'' or ''[[Star Wars: Republic Commando|Republic Commando]]''" and "is being developed by the same people who created ''BioShock 2''." According to the rumor, which was accompanied by several leaked screenshots and repeated by many other publications, the game would be released only for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 and possibly as a $30 downloadable title.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5947737/the-other-xcom-game-might-now-be-a-third+person-shooter |title=The Other XCOM Game Might Now Be a Third-Person Shooter |publisher=Kotaku |date=September 30, 2012 |accessdate=November 27, 2012}} {{Clear}} In April 2013, the game's official website xcom.com/xcom was deleted without any official explanation, while all videos relating to it suddenly disappeared from 2K Games' official [[YouTube]] channel as well. One month earlier, 2K Games had registered the Internet domains thebureau-game.com, thebureau-game.net, whathappenedin62.com, and whathappenedin62.net, indicating that the game might return with a new title, possibly as ''The Bureau''.{{cite web|last=Rosenberg |first=Adam |url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/xcom-shooter-website-official-trailers-disappear-but-what-does-it-all-mean/ |title=Something is going on with the XCOM shooter... |publisher=Digital Trends |date=April 19, 2013 |accessdate=August 3, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oxm.co.uk/52330/has-the-xcom-fps-become-the-bureau/ |title=Xbox 360 News: Has the XCOM FPS become 'The Bureau'? – Xbox 360 – The Official Magazine |publisher=Oxm.co.uk |date= |accessdate=August 3, 2013}} VideoGamer.com received a package containing a dossier labeled "Burn After Opening", containing materials confirming a link between ''XCOM'' and the name "The Bureau".{{cite web|url=http://www.videogamer.com/news/is_2k_about_to_re-announce_xcom.html |title=Is 2K about to re-announce XCOM? – XCOM for Xbox 360 News |publisher=VideoGamer.com |date= |accessdate=August 3, 2013}} GameZone's analysis of a viral teaser video "What Happened in 62" predicted that the redesigned ''XCOM'' would reappear on April 26.{{cite web|last=Liebl |first=Matt |url=http://www.gamezone.com/news/2013/04/23/teaser-suggests-a-reveal-for-2k-s-xcom-shooter-possibly-the-bureau-could-come-this-week |title=Teaser suggests a reveal for 2K's XCOM shooter,... |publisher=GameZone |date= |accessdate=August 3, 2013}} On April 24, 2013, 2K posted an announcement titled "2K Marin's [redacted] is coming soon":{{cite web|url=http://www.2kgames.com/blog/2k-marin-s-redacted-is-coming-soon |title=BLOG – 2K MARIN'S IS COMING SOON |publisher=2K Games |date= |accessdate=August 3, 2013}}
The ''XCOM'' universe is expanding. In the coming days the world will get a fresh look at the long-awaited squad-based tactical shooter in development at 2K Marin. Announced back in 2010, the game has undergone an evolution since we last showed it to you at E3 2011. Firaxis' critically acclaimed turn-based strategy title, ''XCOM: Enemy Unknown'', has reignited the classic franchise and we feel that the time is right to deliver a new experience within the world of ''XCOM''. The creative development of this game has been a collaborative process of discovery and iteration. 2K's culture allows our studios the freedom to refine their visions, to explore new ideas, and to deliver the best possible experiences for players. Through this exploration, 2K Marin has refined their vision, and as a result the game has evolved into a high-stakes narrative experience imbued with core ''XCOM'' concepts. The wait is nearly over and we can't wait to share more details with you about the game in only a matter of days.
''The Bureau: XCOM Declassified'' was officially unveiled as a full-priced title along with a live-action trailer on April 26, with a planned release date of August 20, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2013/04/26/the-bureau-xcom-declassified-detailed-and-described.aspx |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified Detailed And Described – News |publisher=www.GameInformer.com |date=July 30, 2013 |accessdate=August 3, 2013}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/the-bureau-xcom-declassified-arrives-in-august-6407573 |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified arrives in August |publisher=GameSpot.com |date=April 26, 2013 |accessdate=August 3, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/xcom-shooter-re-emerges-as-the-bureau-xcom-declassified-252387.phtml |title=XCOM shooter re-emerges as The Bureau: XCOM Declassified |publisher=Destructoid |date= |accessdate=August 3, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Rosenberg |first=Adam |url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/xcom-shooter-returns-as-the-bureau-xcom-declassified-on-august-20/ |title='The Bureau: XCOM Declassified' proves that even the aliens were cooler in the 60s |publisher=Digital Trends |date=April 26, 2013 |accessdate=August 3, 2013}} The first actual gameplay footage trailer for ''The Bureau'', with developer commentary, was released on May 13, 2013.[http://gamerant.com/the-bureau-xcom-declassified-gameplay-screenshots/ 2K Debuts First Gameplay Footage, New Screens for 'The Bureau: XCOM Declassified'] ==Release== ''The Bureau'' pre-order bonuses included a Light Plasma Pistol weapon and the minor operation "Codebreakers". On October 8, 2013, [[downloadable content]] ''Hangar 6 R&D'' was released for the Xbox 360, containing a series of missions set shortly before the main game that follow Nico DaSilva, as he takes part in psychic experiments in order to combat the Sleepwalker virus. DaSilva also possesses new abilities and perks and can acquire new weapons, such as the [[AK-47]] and Microwave Gun. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GR = (X360) 69.96%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/xbox360/995203-the-bureau-xcom-declassified/index.html |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified for Xbox 360 |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=August 23, 2013}}
(PS3) 65.56%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps3/632699-the-bureau-xcom-declassified/index.html |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified for PlayStation 3 |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=August 23, 2013}}
(PC) 61.91%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/995202-the-bureau-xcom-declassified/index.html |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified for PC |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=August 23, 2013}} | MC = (PS3) 69/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/the-bureau-xcom-declassified |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified for PlayStation 3 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=August 23, 2013}}
(X360) 68/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/the-bureau-xcom-declassified |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified for Xbox 360 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=August 23, 2013}}
(PC) 66/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/the-bureau-xcom-declassified |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified for PC Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=August 23, 2013}} | Destruct = 4.5/10{{cite web |last=Sterling |first=Jim |date=August 19, 2013 |url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-the-bureau-xcom-declassified-260320.phtml |title=Review: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified |work=[[Destructoid]] |accessdate=August 22, 2013}} | EuroG = 7/10{{cite web |last=Whitehead |first=Dan |date=August 20, 2013 |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-08-20-the-bureau-xcom-declassified-review |title=The Bureau: XCOM Declassified review |work=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=August 22, 2013}} | Joystiq = {{rating|4|5}}{{cite web |last=Kietzmann |first=Ludwig |date=August 20, 2013 |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2013/08/20/the-bureau-xcom-declassified-review/ |title=The Bureau – XCOM Declassified review: Mad men are from mars |work=[[Joystiq]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |accessdate=August 22, 2013}} }} The initial public reaction to the reveal of the ''XCOM'' reboot in 2010 was negative.{{cite web|url=http://www.neoseeker.com/news/17428-2k-marin-explains-xcom-remake-and-origins-in-first-developer-video/ |title=2K Marin explains XCOM remake and origins in first developer video |publisher=Neoseeker |date=September 22, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Biessener |first=Adam |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2012/01/05/february-cover-revealed-xcom-enemy-unknown.aspx |title=February Cover Revealed: XCOM: Enemy Unknown – News |publisher=www.GameInformer.com |date=January 5, 2012 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Staff |first=Techland |url=http://techland.time.com/2012/01/24/sid-meier-talks-xcom-enemy-unknown-remakes-action-rpg-angles/ |title=Sid Meier Talks XCOM: Enemy Unknown Remake’s Action, RPG Angles | Techland | TIME.com |publisher=Techland.time.com |date=January 24, 2012 |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} [[Destructoid]] called it "the first-person shooter that the Internet loves to hate",{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/2k-marin-s-xcom-hit-with-yet-another-delay-227875.phtml |title=2K Marin's XCOM hit with yet another delay |publisher=Destructoid |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} and ''[[UFO: Enemy Unknown]]'' designer and ''X-COM'' series creator [[Julian Gollop]] criticized the original-announcement version of the game for abandoning the turn-based combat system of the original games.{{cite web|first=Alex|last=Wiltshire |url=http://www.edge-online.com/features/julian-gollop-xcom |title=Julian Gollop on XCOM – Edge Magazine |publisher=Edge-online.com |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2012/01/x-com-creator-2k-marins-fps-a-great-shame/ |title=X-COM Creator: 2K Marin’s FPS A ‘Great Shame’ | Kotaku Australia |publisher=Kotaku.com.au |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}} Gollop later suggested that the "1950s style alternate reality thing" and FPS nature of the game had not been well received, although he thought that graphically the game was "amazing".{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2013/04/25/x-coms-creator-julian-gollop-on-new-xcom-would-i-have-designed-the-game-in-the-same-way-i-would-have-to-say-no/ |title=X-Com creator Julian Gollop on how he would have designed Enemy Unknown differently, and why it would have failed | News |publisher=PC Gamer |date=April 25, 2013 |accessdate=August 3, 2013}} The reactions improved when ''XCOM'' was re-designed with third-person viewpoints and a tactical pause mode. [[1UP.com]] called the revised version "the [[dark horse]]" of [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2011|E3 2011]]. According to [[IGN]], "''XCOM'' the FPS was announced before [[XCOM: Enemy Unknown|the strategy remake]], so fans cried foul at defiling such a sacred series. But with top-notch style and a focus on team-based combat, the new take on ''XCOM'' might turn fans into believers when it finally releases in 2013."{{cite web |url=http://uk.games.ign.com/articles/121/1218958p1.html |title=10 Series That Changed Beyond Recognition – Games Feature at IGN |publisher=Uk.games.ign.com |date=February 17, 2012 |accessdate=November 27, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120221023204/http://uk.games.ign.com/articles/121/1218958p1.html |archivedate=February 21, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ''The Bureau: XCOM Declassified'' received generally mixed or average reviews. Aggregating review websites [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] gave the Xbox 360 version 69.96% and 68/100, the PlayStation 3 version 65.56% and 69/100 and the PC version 61.91% and 66/100. Dan Whitehead of [[Eurogamer]] gave the game a score of 7/10, arguing that while the game was not necessary in the wake of ''Enemy Unknown'', it can still be enjoyed as a tactical shooter. [[Joystiq]]'s Ludwig Kietzmann praised the game's open-ended environments and gave the game four stars out of five. [[Destructoid]]'s Jim Sterling, however, opined that the game "wants to be ''XCOM'' without being ''XCOM''. As such, it is nothing," criticising the strategy elements and ultimately giving the game a rating of 4.5 out of 10. {{clear}} ==See also== * ''[[X-COM: Alliance]]'', a canceled first-person tactical shooter game in development between 1995 and the early 2000s * ''[[X-COM: Enforcer]]'', a third-person shooter based on the first ''X-COM'' game ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.thebureau-game.com/}} {{X-COM}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bureau: XCOM Declassified, The}} [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Alien invasions in video games]] [[Category:Alternate history video games]] [[Category:Fictional government investigations of the paranormal]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:Science fiction video games]] [[Category:Tactical shooter video games]] [[Category:Take-Two Interactive games]] [[Category:Third-person shooters]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Video games set in 1962]] [[Category:Video games set in the United States]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:X-COM]] [[Category:Video games using PhysX]]

{{Orphan|date=November 2012}}
'''The Miniature White House''' is a detailed miniature [[replica]] of the [[White House]] created by miniaturists John and Jan Zweifel.<ref name="AmPro">{{cite news | url= http://www.americanprofile.com/heroes/article/5341.html | title= A Gift to the Nation | publisher=''American Profile'' | date=June 4, 2006 | accessdate=October 7, 2009}}</ref><ref name="KCStar">{{cite news | url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=KC&p_theme=kc&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF43B30E6C84F5&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | title=It's a small world: The house that John Zweifel built is a miniature version of America's most famous residence | publisher=''[[The Kansas City Star]]'' | date=November 19, 1996 | accessdate=October 7, 2009}}</ref><ref name="Tribune">{{cite news | url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/744908852.html?dids=744908852:744908852&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Aug+23%2C+1985&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Roving+White+House+replica+is+a+special+gift+to+the+American+people&pqatl=google| title=Roving White House replica is a special gift to the American people | publisher=''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' | date=August 23, 1985 | accessdate=October 7, 2009 | first=Phyllis | last=Magida}}</ref>
Its construction began in 1962, on a 1-inch to 1 foot scale.<ref name="AmPro"/> It was created in painstaking detail, and features miniature replications of almost all the rooms in the [[White House]], including the [[East Wing]], [[West Wing]] and the [[Oval Office]]. It has toured every U.S. state<ref name="AmPro"/> as well as several foreign countries while on tour in the 1970s and early 1980s. While touring in the [[Netherlands]], the replica was attacked by a group of anti-American vandals, who significantly damaged most of the model, but all was eventually repaired. Portions of the replica can be seen at the Presidents Hall of Fame museum [http://www.presidentshalloffame.com/] in [[Clermont, Florida]], while the replica itself is featured on tour (usually displayed in [[presidential libraries]]) from time to time.
A detailed, illustrated book by Gail Buckland, '''''The White House in Miniature''''', was published in 1994 and features an extensive history of the replica, its creators and features a photographic tour of all the miniature rooms. A [[VHS]]/[[DVD]] tour of the replica has also been made available.
The replica's permanent location is at the Zweifel's ''Presidents Hall of Fame'' in [[Clermont, Florida]].<ref name="AmPro"/>
== See also == * [[Replicas of the White House]]

revision.text:
[[File:Trevor H. Hall.png|thumb|Trevor. H. Hall]] '''Trevor Henry Hall''' (1910–1991) was a British author, surveyor, and [[Scepticism|sceptic]] of [[paranormal]] phenomena.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/trevor-henry-hall Gale Encyclopedia of Occultism and Parapsychology]</ref> Hall made controversial claims regarding early members of the [[Society for Psychical Research]]. His books caused a heated controversy within the [[parapsychology]] community.<ref name="Kurtz 1985">Hövelmann. Gerd H; Truzzi, Marcello; Hoebens, Piet Hein. (1985). ''Skeptical Literature on Parapsychology: An Annotated Bibliography''. In [[Paul Kurtz]]. ''A Skeptic's Handbook of Parapsychology''. Prometheus Books. pp. 449-490. {{ISBN|0-87975-300-5}}</ref>
==Career== Hall was born in Wakefield, England. He served as a major in the British army during [[World War II]] (1939–45) and became a senior partner of V. Walker and Son (chartered surveyors) (1945–80), he was the vice president of the Huddersfield Building Society (1958–80).<ref>The Estates Gazette. (1971). Volume 220. p. 505</ref>
He had a deep interest in [[Magic (illusion)|magic]] and mystery. Hall was a student in [[Parapsychology|psychical research]] at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] (1954–56). His knowledge of conjuring and magic helped him discover the tricks of [[mediumship|mediums]], many of whom had been caught in fraud. Hall was an ex-member and critic of the Society for Psychical Research and published a series of sceptical books on the paranormal and psychical research.<ref>Luckhurst, Roger. (2002). ''The Invention of Telepathy: 1870-1901''. Oxford University Press. p. 2. {{ISBN|0-19-924962-8}}</ref> He was a collector of magic books and was a member of [[The Magic Circle (organisation)|The Magic Circle]]. He also wrote three books on the higher criticism of [[Sherlock Holmes]].
==Research==
===Florence Cook===
In his controversial book ''The Spiritualists'' (1962), Hall stated that the famous medium [[Florence Cook]] was a fraud who had an affair with the chemist and psychical researcher [[William Crookes]].<ref>Cohen, Daniel. (1971). ''Masters of the Occult''. Dodd, Mead & Company. p. 111. {{ISBN|978-0396064077}} "In 1962 Trevor H. Hall, a British jurist and psychical researcher, re-examined the Crooke's-Cook case and came to the sensational conclusion not that Crookes had been fooled (as many had believed) but that he was an active participant in the hoax, and that he had a sexual involvement with the attractive medium. Though all the figures in this case were long dead the charge stirred up furor in the very tradition-minded psychical research circles in England. The controversy reverberates to this day."</ref><ref>Williams, William F. (2000). ''Encyclopedia of Pseudoscience: From Alien Abductions to Zone Therapy''. Routledge. p. 67. {{ISBN|1-57958-207-9}}</ref>
Hall drew upon Francis G. H. Anderson's statements to the Society for Psychical Research in 1922 and 1941. Anderson claimed to have had an affair with Cook himself, he also stated that she was a sexual maniac who confessed to having an affair with Crookes.<ref>Tromp, Marlene. (2006). ''Altered States: Sex, Nation, Drugs, and Self-Transformation in Victorian Spiritualism.'' State University of New York Press. pp. 43-44. {{ISBN|978-0-7914-6739-8}}</ref> In 1964, psychical researchers R. G. Medhurst and [[K. M. Goldney]] cast considerable doubt on the reliability of Anderson's testimony and dismissed Hall's allegations. Biographer [[William Hodson Brock]] who has praised Hall's book also doubted the claims of an affair.<ref>[[William Hodson Brock|Brock, William Hodson]]. (2008). ''William Crookes (1832-1919) and the Commercialization of Science''. Ashgate Publishing. pp. 184-185. {{ISBN|978-0-7546-6322-5}}</ref>
Regarding Hall's research that Cook had an affair with Crookes, historian [[Asa Briggs]] in a review commented that "the verdict does not seem to be fully proven, although the evidence is striking".<ref>Briggs, Asa. (1965). ''Reviewed Works: The Spiritualists: The Story of Florence Cook and William Crookes by Trevor H. Hall; The First Five Lives of Annie Besant by Arthur H. Nethercot; The Last Four Lives of Annie Besant by Arthur H. Nethercot''. ''[[Victorian Studies]]''. Vol. 8, No. 4, pp. 361-363.</ref>
Psychologist [[Ray Hyman]] has noted that despite how one may consider the allegations, "there is no question that Hall has unearthed much material that throws strong suspicions on Crookes's handling of this investigation."<ref>Hyman, Ray. (1989). ''The Elusive Quarry: A Scientific Appraisal of Psychical Research''. Prometheus Books. p. 209. {{ISBN|0-87975-504-0}}</ref> Researchers such as [[Ruth Brandon]] and [[Eric Dingwall]] have supported Hall's arguments against Cook and Crookes.<ref>[[Ruth Brandon|Brandon, Ruth]]. (1983). ''The Spiritualists: The Passion for the Occult in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries''. Weidenfeld and Nicolson. pp. 122-124. {{ISBN|978-0297782490}}</ref><ref>Brandon, Ruth. (1985). [https://books.google.com/books?id=p6DGWU27baYC&pg=PA52&dq=%22Unsavoury+Spirits%22+New+Scientist&hl=en&sa=X&ei=au95VIfmMo24afCbgvgK&ved=0CCsQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Unsavoury%20Spirits%22%20New%20Scientist&f=false ''Unsavoury Spirits'']. New Scientist 18 July. p. 52.</ref><ref>Hansel, C. E. M. (1989). ''The Search for Psychic Power: ESP and Parapsychology Revisited''. Prometheus Books. p. 287. {{ISBN|0-87975-516-4}} "In his ''Critics Dilemma'' (1966) he revealed that in 1922 he had himself met the man to whom Florence Cook had given details of her affair with Crookes, her trips to Paris, and the assistance that Crookes had provided in order to fake the spirit Katie King. Dingwall supported Hall's conclusions and after considering attempts to explain away the evidence writes "If we are being asked to think that Crookes really believed in all of this, it appears his modern defenders are reducing him almost to the level of an imbecile and denigrating him to a far greater degree than Mr. Hall has done."</ref>
===Edmund Gurney=== In his book ''The Strange Case of Edmund Gurney'' (1964), Hall made the claim that [[Edmund Gurney]] committed suicide after discovering the frauds of [[Douglas Blackburn]] and [[George Albert Smith (film pioneer)|George Albert Smith]]. This has been strongly contested by biographer Trevor Hamilton and the psychical researcher [[Alan Gauld]].<ref>Hayward, Rhodri. (2007). ''Resisting History: Religious Transcendence and the Invention of the Unconscious''. Manchester University Press. p. 72. {{ISBN|978-0-7190-7414-1}}</ref><ref>Hamilton, Trevor. (2009). ''Immortal Longings: F.W.H. Myers and the Victorian Search for Life After Death''. Imprint Academic. pp. 164-169. {{ISBN|978-1-8454-0248-8}}</ref>
Parapsychologist Fraser Nicol published an extremely negative review of Hall's book on Gurney, this caused a threat of a libel action from Hall.<ref>Wiley, Barry H. (2012). ''The Thought Reader Craze: Victorian Science at the Enchanted Boundary''. McFarland. p. 224. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-6470-8}}</ref><ref>Hamilton, Trevor. (2013). ''F. W. H. Myers, William James, and Spiritualism''. In Christopher M. Moreman. ''The Spiritualist Movement: Speaking with the Dead in America and Around the World''. ''Volume 1: American Origins and Global Proliferation''. [[Greenwood Publishing Group|Praeger]]. pp. 97-114. {{ISBN|978-0-313-39947-3}}</ref>
===Daniel Dunglas Home===
In his book ''The Enigma of Daniel Home: Medium or Fraud?'' (1984), Hall asserted that the medium [[Daniel Dunglas Home]] had invented his aristocratic background.<ref>[[Gordon Stein|Stein, Gordon]]. (1993). ''The Sorcerer of Kings: The Case of Daniel Dunglas Home and William Crookes''. Prometheus Books. p. 71. {{ISBN|0-87975-863-5}} "It remained for Trevor Hall to show that Home's middle name, "Dunglas," which represents one of the noble Scottish families, was really just an affectation. In other words, although he often claimed the descent of his father as a natural [i.e., illegitimate] son of Alexander, tenth Earl of Home," was actually not related to that family, and therefore not a Dunglas. In addition, his birth certificate does not have "Dunglas" on it; it's simply Daniel Home."</ref>
Hall's research led him to conclude that the alleged [[levitation (paranormal)|levitation]] of Home at Ashley House never happened as the eyewitness reports contradicted each other and all Home did was step across a gap of four feet between two iron balconies.<ref>Smith, F. B. (1986). ''Reviewed Works: The Enigma of Daniel Home: Medium or Fraud? by Trevor H. Hall; The Spiritualists: The Passion for the Occult in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries by Ruth Brandon; The Other World: Spiritualism and Psychical Research in England, 1850-1914 by Janet Oppenheim''. ''[[Victorian Studies]]''. Vol. 29, No. 4, pp. 613-614.</ref>
==Reception==
Researcher [[Georgess McHargue]] noted that Hall was "one of the most astute of modern investigators, combining twentieth-century scientific techniques with a cheerful and readable writing style in his many books."<ref>[[Georgess McHargue|McHargue, Georgess]]. (1972). ''Facts, Frauds, and Phantasms: A Survey of the Spiritualist Movement''. Doubleday. p. 100. {{ISBN|978-0385053051}}</ref> However, [[Roger Luckhurst]] has written that Halls "books proceed with a combination of careful archival work and abusive character assassinations."<ref>Luckhurst, Roger. (2002). ''The Invention of Telepathy, 1870-1901''. Oxford University Press. pp. 74-75. {{ISBN|0-19-924962-8}}</ref>
In the book ''A Skeptic's Handbook of Parapsychology'' (1985), authors Gerd H. Hövelmann, [[Marcello Truzzi]] and [[Piet Hein Hoebens]] noted that "[al]though Hall's historical detective work is often impressive, his conclusions sometimes go beyond his data. Despite the flaws in some of Hall's efforts, his writings should be required reading for everyone interested in early psychical research."<ref name="Kurtz 1985"/>

(1969). ''Reviewed Work: Strange Things by John L. Campbell, Trevor H. Hall''. ''[[Folklore (journal)|Folklore]]''. Vol. 80, No. 3. pp. 224-227.</ref> *''Sherlock Holmes: Ten Literary Studies'' (1969) *''The Late Mr Sherlock Holmes: and Other Literary Studies'' (1971) *''Old Conjuring Books'' (1973) *''The Early Years of the Huddersfield Building Society'' (1974) *''Sherlock Holmes and his Creator'' (1977) *''Search for Harry Price'' (1980) *''The Enigma of Daniel Home: Medium or Fraud?'' {{Other uses}} {{Multiple issues| {{cleanup rewrite|date=January 2012}} {{original research|date=April 2012}} }} <!-- Dispute & rewrite have not been discussed in Talk, nor are there any OR tags on sections needing work. --> '''Valley girl''' is a [[socio-economic]] [[stereotype]] depicting a class of women characterized by the colloquial [[California English]] dialect ''[[Valleyspeak]]'' and [[Economic materialism|materialism]].
Originally referring to upper-middle class girls from the [[Los Angeles]] commuter communities of the [[San Fernando Valley]] during the 1980s, the term in later years became more broadly applied to any female in the [[United States]] who engendered the associated affects of [[wikt:ditz|ditziness]], [[wikt:airhead|airheadedness]], and/or greater interest in [[conspicuous consumption]] than intellectual or personal accomplishment.<ref>Demarest, Michael; Stanley, Alessandra (September 27, 1982). [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,925750,00.html "Living: How Toe-dully Max Is Their Valley:]. ''Time'' magazine.</ref>
==In popular culture== In 1982, composer [[Frank Zappa]] released the single "[[Valley Girl (song)|Valley Girl]]", with his 14-year-old daughter [[Moon Unit Zappa|Moon Unit]] speaking typical "Valley Girl" phrases. Zappa intended to lampoon the image, but after the song's release there was a significant increase in the "Valspeak" slang usage, whether ironically spoken or not.<ref>{{cite book | title = Frank Zappa: The Negative Dialectics of Poodle Play| first1 = Ben| last1 = Watson| publisher = Quartet Books| year = 1994| page=396|isbn=978-0-7033-7066-2}}</ref>
The 1983 film ''[[Valley Girl (film)|Valley Girl]]'' starring [[Nicolas Cage]] centered on a group of "Valley Girl" characters and featured several characterizations associated with their lifestyle (such as going shopping at the mall or "[[Sherman Oaks Galleria|Galleria]]," suntanning at the beach, and going to parties).
The protagonist of the 1995 film ''[[Clueless (film)|Clueless]]'' has been described as a caricature of 1990s Valley Girls, though she is actually from nearby [[Beverly Hills]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Amy Irving|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/72012243/|accessdate=8 April 2015|agency=The Index-Journal|date=April 22, 1998}}</ref><ref name=1990s>{{cite book|last1=Alan Schwartz|first1=Richard|title=The 1990s|date=2006|publisher=Infobase Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HMLGas7fOyYC&pg=PA236&lpg=PA236&dq=Clueless+%221990s+valley+girl%22&source=bl&ots=-VKM_jKJLf&sig=Xz31szoJTKQYJBXhXfjh6n_EANo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UnclVZszhrCwBI3egfgJ&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Clueless%20%221990s%20valley%20girl%22&f=false|accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=time>{{cite news|last1=Rothman|first1=Lily|title=No Rebuttals: The Top 10 Movie Debate Scenes|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2012/10/22/no-rebuttals-the-top-10-movie-debate-scenes/slide/clueless/|website=Time.com|publisher=Time|accessdate=8 April 2015|date=22 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=nytimes>{{cite news|last1=Hoffman|first1=Jan|title=Overturning the Myth of Valley Girl Speak|url=http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/12/23/overturning-the-myth-of-valley-girl-speak/?_r=0|website=NYTimes.com|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=8 April 2015|date=23 December 2013}}</ref>
In her 2015 memoir entitled ''Wildflower'', actress [[Drew Barrymore]] says she talks "like a valley girl" because she lived in [[Sherman Oaks, Los Angeles|Sherman Oaks]] from the age of 7 to 14.<ref name="wildflower7">{{cite book|last1=Barrymore|first1=Drew|title=Wildflower|date=2015|publisher=Dutton|location=New York|isbn=9781101983799|oclc=904421431|pages=2; 7|quote=As if I had been lobotomized, we packed our things and moved into our new home, indeed in Sherman Oaks, in 1983. It's why I still talk like a valley girl. That cadence snuck into my life at that spongelike age of eight and never left.}}</ref>
